summary: A magazine profile of Jeffrey Epstein from the early 2000s, detailing his mysterious background as a financier, his connections to high-profile figures like Bill Clinton, Donald Trump, and Leslie Wexner, his lavish lifestyle, and his intellectual pursuits funding scientists. The article portrays Epstein as a secretive, Gatsby-esque figure who managed billions for ultra-wealthy clients.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the article, described as a mysterious, wealthy money manager with connections to politicians, celebrities, and scientists. He flies Bill Clinton to Africa and manages billions for clients.

persons.name: Leslie Wexner
persons.role: Founder and chairman of The Limited
persons.context: Described as Epstein's patron, mentor, and client. Epstein reportedly managed his money and was involved in his New Albany real estate development. Epstein lives in a Manhattan mansion originally bought by Wexner.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Linked to Epstein for over ten years, described as a 'soul mate' though their relationship is mysterious. She is said to have introduced him to a higher-octane social scene.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Describes Epstein as a 'terrific guy' and 'lot of fun,' noting Epstein's liking for beautiful women, including younger ones. Known Epstein for fifteen years.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.role: Former President of the United States
persons.context: Epstein flew him, Kevin Spacey, and Chris Tucker to Africa on his private plane. Epstein is described as viewing Clinton as the 'world's greatest politician' and a prize addition to his collection of influential people.

persons.name: Kevin Spacey
persons.context: Traveled to Africa with Clinton on Epstein's private Boeing 727, described as a close friend of Clinton's.

persons.name: Chris Tucker
persons.context: Traveled to Africa with Clinton on Epstein's private Boeing 727.

persons.name: Ace Greenberg
persons.context: Epstein was recommended to him. Greenberg favored 'PSDs' (poor, smart, deep desire to be rich), which fit Epstein. Epstein worked at Bear Stearns starting in 1976.

persons.name: Jimmy Cayne
persons.context: Described Epstein's role at Bear Stearns in the special-products division advising wealthy clients on tax implications, calling him a 'very smart guy' and an important client.

persons.name: David Patrick Columbia
persons.context: Commented on the mysterious relationship between Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, calling them 'soul mates' yet hardly companions.

persons.name: Jeffrey T. Leeds
persons.role: Private equity executive at Leeds Weld & Co.
persons.context: Defended Epstein as more than a social figure, calling him a talented money manager and hardworking person who is not a self-promoter.

persons.name: Dennis Block
persons.role: M&A lawyer at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft
persons.context: Sent a $500 million client to Epstein, who refused the account for being too small, confirming Epstein's high entry threshold and that he has clients beyond Leslie Wexner.

persons.name: Bob Fitrakis
persons.context: Commented on Epstein's role in cleaning up the financial preparations for Leslie Wexner's New Albany development and organizing events for Wexner.

persons.name: Doug Band
persons.context: Pitched the idea of the Africa trip to Epstein, who agreed to provide his plane.

persons.name: George Mitchell
persons.context: Described by Epstein as the 'world's greatest negotiator.' Epstein wrote him checks and organized a fundraiser, with Mitchell calling him a friend and supporter.

persons.name: Gerald Edelman
persons.context: One of the scientists Epstein funds. Praised Epstein's ability to pick up on quantitative relations and his interest in whether the brain is a computer.

persons.name: Stephen Kosslyn
persons.context: Epstein funded his research on Tibetan monks' mental imagery. Described Epstein as amazing, like a honeybee who cross-pollinates ideas.

persons.name: Martin Nowak
persons.role: Biology and mathematics professor at Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton
persons.context: Has a close relationship with Epstein, who funds his research on game theory and evolution. Epstein talks to him weekly and flew him to meet Bill Clinton.

persons.name: Danny Hillis
persons.context: Thinks Epstein uses scientific knowledge to beat the markets, discussing currency trading with him and crediting him with valuable investment advice.

persons.name: Murray Gell-Mann
persons.context: Friend of Epstein's, with whom Epstein discussed elementary particle physics, leading Epstein to build a house in Santa Fe.

persons.name: Al D'Amato
persons.context: Mentioned as a recipient of Epstein's political contributions, contrasting with Epstein's support for Democrat Bill Clinton.

persons.name: Landon Thomas Jr.
persons.context: Writer of the magazine profile on Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as someone one might see at a party at Ghislaine Maxwell's house, indicating social circles.

persons.name: Linda Wachner
persons.context: Rumored to have been a client of Epstein's, but the relationship is denied.

persons.name: David Rockefeller
persons.context: Rumored to have been a client of Epstein's, but the relationship is denied.

connections.description: Wexner is Epstein's patron, mentor, and client. Epstein manages his money, was involved in his New Albany real estate project, and lives in a mansion originally bought by Wexner.
Linked for over ten years in a mysterious relationship described as being 'soul mates.' Maxwell introduced Epstein to high-society circles.
Epstein flew Clinton to Africa on his private plane. Epstein admires Clinton as a politician, and Clinton praised Epstein's insights and generosity.
Trump has known Epstein for fifteen years, calls him a 'terrific guy' and 'lot of fun,' and notes their shared appreciation for beautiful women.
Greenberg hired Epstein at Bear Stearns in 1976 after a recommendation. Epstein fit Greenberg's preference for 'PSDs' (poor, smart, deep desire to be rich).
Epstein funds Nowak's research to the tune of $500,000, talks to him weekly, flies him around, and introduced him to Bill Clinton.
Spacey traveled with Clinton on Epstein's plane to Africa.
Tucker traveled with Clinton on Epstein's plane to Africa.
Described as close friends; traveled together on Epstein's plane to Africa.
Prince Andrew is mentioned as someone one might see at a party at Maxwell's house.

events.title: Epstein flies Clinton, Spacey, Tucker to Africa
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein uses his private Boeing 727 to fly former President Bill Clinton, actor Kevin Spacey, and actor Chris Tucker on a tour of African nations including South Africa, Nigeria, Ghana, Rwanda, and Mozambique. The trip draws significant media attention to Epstein.

events.title: Epstein begins career at Bear Stearns
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein starts working at Bear Stearns as a junior assistant to a floor trader at the American Stock Exchange after being recommended to Ace Greenberg.

events.title: Epstein made partner at Bear Stearns
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is made a partner at Bear Stearns, but leaves the firm by 1981 to start his own business.

events.title: Epstein founds J. Epstein and Co.
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein establishes his own money management firm, J. Epstein and Co. (later Financial Trust Co.), catering exclusively to clients with $1 billion or more.

events.title: Leslie Wexner becomes Epstein client
events.description: Leslie Wexner, founder of The Limited, becomes a client of Jeffrey Epstein, marking the beginning of their deep financial and personal relationship.

events.title: Epstein acquires 71st Street mansion from Wexner
events.description: Leslie Wexner turns over the 45,000-square-foot Manhattan mansion on East 71st Street to Jeffrey Epstein after Wexner's marriage. Epstein then undertakes a $10 million renovation.

locations: Manhattan, New York (Epstein's 71st Street mansion, Villard House office)
St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands (Epstein's private island, Financial Trust Co. office)
New Albany, Ohio (Wexner's development, Epstein's former house)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein managed an estimated $15 billion for ultra-wealthy clients, requiring a minimum of $1 billion to invest with him.
Epstein's client list was secret, but Leslie Wexner was a confirmed client and patron; Epstein was deeply involved in Wexner's New Albany real estate project.
Epstein flew former President Bill Clinton, Kevin Spacey, and Chris Tucker to Africa on his private Boeing 727, which brought him significant media attention.
Epstein cultivated relationships with Nobel Prize-winning scientists and other intellectuals, funding their research to the tune of millions annually.
Epstein lived a lavish, secretive lifestyle, owning multiple massive properties including the largest private house in Manhattan and a private island in St. Thomas.
